conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on both blocks A and B.
Block B is in contact with block A and is just about to slide down.
The forces acting on block B are gravitational force, normal force, and frictional force.
Frictional force on B is at its maximum static friction value.
Frictional force is given by f_{AB} = μ_1 N_B.
Block B is in equilibrium vertically, so N_B = m_B g.
Block A is just about to slip.
The forces acting on block A are gravitational force, normal force, frictional force from the ground, normal force from B, and frictional force from B.
Block A is in equilibrium vertically, so N_A = m_A g + f_{AB}.
Frictional force f_{AG} is at its maximum static friction value: f_{AG} = μ_2 N_A.
From equilibrium of block B, f_{AB} = μ_1 m_B g.
From equilibrium of block A, N_A = m_A g + μ_1 m_B g and f_{AG} = μ_2 (m_A g + μ_1 m_B g).
Since block A is just about to slip, μ_2 (m_A g + μ_1 m_B g) = m_B g.
Divide both sides by g: μ_2 (m_A + μ_1 m_B) = m_B.
Rearrange to solve for m_A: μ_2 m_A + μ_1 μ_2 m_B = m_B.
The mass ratio of A to B is (1 - μ_1 μ_2) / μ_2.
